Line 46: Line 46:
[[Political corruption]] in Mubarak administration's [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]] has risen dramatically, due to the increased power over the institutional system necessary to prolong the presidency.<ref name="Egypt after Mubarak">{{Cite book|last=Rutherford|first=Bruce|title=Egypt after Mubarak: Liberalism, Islam, and Democracy in the Arab World|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=2008|month=November|isbn= 0-6911-3665-3}}</ref> The rise to power of powerful business men in the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] in the government and the People's Assembly led to massive waves of anger during the years of Prime Ministers [[Ahmed Nazif]]'s government. An example of that is [[Ahmed Ezz]]'s [[Monopoly|monopolizing]] the steel industry in Egypt by holding more than 60 percent of the market share.<ref name="Emerging Egypt 2007">{{Cite book|last=|first=|title=The Report: Egypt 2007|publisher=[[Oxford Business Group]]|year=2007|month=January|isbn= 1-9023-3957-6}}</ref> Aladdin Elaasar, an Egyptian biographer and an American professor, estimates that the Mubarak family is worth from $50 to $70 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/aladdin-elaasar/egyptians-rise-against-th_b_815520.html |title=Egyptians Rise Against Their Pharoah |work=[[Huffington Post]] |last=Elaasar |first=Aladdin |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/egypt-mubarak-family-accumulated-wealth-days-military/story?id=12821073&page=2|title=Egypt's Mubarak Likely to Retain Vast Wealth|publisher=[[ABC NEWS]]|accessdate=05 February 2011}}</ref>
[[Political corruption]] in Mubarak administration's [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]] has risen dramatically, due to the increased power over the institutional system necessary to prolong the presidency.<ref name="Egypt after Mubarak">{{Cite book|last=Rutherford|first=Bruce|title=Egypt after Mubarak: Liberalism, Islam, and Democracy in the Arab World|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=2008|month=November|isbn= 0-6911-3665-3}}</ref> The rise to power of powerful business men in the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] in the government and the People's Assembly led to massive waves of anger during the years of Prime Ministers [[Ahmed Nazif]]'s government. An example of that is [[Ahmed Ezz]]'s [[Monopoly|monopolizing]] the steel industry in Egypt by holding more than 60 percent of the market share.<ref name="Emerging Egypt 2007">{{Cite book|last=|first=|title=The Report: Egypt 2007|publisher=[[Oxford Business Group]]|year=2007|month=January|isbn= 1-9023-3957-6}}</ref> Aladdin Elaasar, an Egyptian biographer and an American professor, estimates that the Mubarak family is worth from $50 to $70 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/aladdin-elaasar/egyptians-rise-against-th_b_815520.html |title=Egyptians Rise Against Their Pharoah |work=[[Huffington Post]] |last=Elaasar |first=Aladdin |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/egypt-mubarak-family-accumulated-wealth-days-military/story?id=12821073&page=2|title=Egypt's Mubarak Likely to Retain Vast Wealth|publisher=[[ABC NEWS]]|accessdate=05 February 2011}}</ref>
â
The wealth of Ahmed Ezz, the former NDP Organisation Secretary, is estimated to be 18 billion Egyptian pounds<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions"><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allheadlinenews.com/briefs/articles/90033584?Obama%20optimistic%20about%20Egypt%20as%20negotiators%20make%20concessions|title=Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions|publisher=AHN|accessdate=09 February 2011}}</ref>; The wealth of former Housing Minister Ahmed al-Maghraby is estimated to be more than 11 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions"/> The wealth of former Minister of Tourism Zuhair Garrana is estimated to be 13 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions"/> The wealth of former Minister of Trade and Industry, Rashid Mohamed Rashid, is estimated to be 12 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions"/> and The wealth of former Interior Minister Habib al-Adly is estimated to be 8 billion Egyptian pounds.<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions"/>
+
The wealth of Ahmed Ezz, the former NDP Organisation Secretary, is estimated to be 18 billion Egyptian pounds<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions">{{cite web|url=http://www.allheadlinenews.com/briefs/articles/90033584?Obama%20optimistic%20about%20Egypt%20as%20negotiators%20make%20concessions|title=Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions|publisher=AHN|accessdate=09 February 2011}}</ref>; The wealth of former Housing Minister Ahmed al-Maghraby is estimated to be more than 11 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions"/> The wealth of former Minister of Tourism Zuhair Garrana is estimated to be 13 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions"/> The wealth of former Minister of Trade and Industry, Rashid Mohamed Rashid, is estimated to be 12 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions"/> and The wealth of former Interior Minister Habib al-Adly is estimated to be 8 billion Egyptian pounds.<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions"/>
In 2010, [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] report assessed Egypt with a CPI score of 3.1, based on perceptions of the degree of corruption from business people and country analysts (with 10 being clean and 0 being totally corrupt).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results|title=CPI 2010 table|publisher=[[Transparency International]]|accessdate=26 October 2010}}</ref>
In 2010, [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] report assessed Egypt with a CPI score of 3.1, based on perceptions of the degree of corruption from business people and country analysts (with 10 being clean and 0 being totally corrupt).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results|title=CPI 2010 table|publisher=[[Transparency International]]|accessdate=26 October 2010}}</ref>
